html:
Etymology[edit]

Contraction of *dēhibeō, from dē- +‎ habeō (“have”). See the same contraction in dēbilis.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈdeː.be.oː/, [ˈd̪eː.be.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈde.be.o/, [ˈd̪ɛː.bɛ.ɔ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Verb[edit]

dēbeō (present infinitive dēbēre, perfect active dēbuī, supine dēbitum); second conjugation

  1. to have or keep from someone
  2. to owe something, to be under obligation to and for something
  3. to be bound, in duty bound to do something; "I ought", "I must", "I should"

Derived terms[edit]

  • dēbitiō
  • dēbitor
  • dēbitrix
  • dēbitum

Descendants[edit]

  • Asturian: deber
  • Catalan: deure
  • Corsican: duveri
  • Dalmatian: dovar
  • English: endeavor, devoir, due
  • Friulian: dovê
  • Galician: deber
  • Italian: dovere
  • Ladin: dovei
  • Ligurian: dovéi
  • Occitan: dever, deure
  • Old French: deveir
    • French: devoir
    • Angevin: devair
    • Gallo: devair
    • Lorrain: devor
    • Norman: deveir
    • Picard: dvoér
    • Walloon: diveur
  • Old Portuguese: dever
    • Portuguese: dever
  • Sardinian: dèpere, depi, dèpiri, dèvere
  • Sicilian: duviri
  • Spanish: deber
  • Venetian: dover

Synonyms[edit]

  • necesse est
  • oportet
  • cogo
  • decet
  • opus est
  • par est
  • meum, tuum ... alicuius est

References[edit]

  • debeo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • debeo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • debeo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to owe gratitude to; to be under an obligation to a person: gratiam alicui debere
    • to owe some one money: pecuniam alicui debere
    • the debtor: debitor, or is qui debet
    • the creditor: creditor, or is cui debeo
    • from this it appears, is apparent: ex quo intellegitur or intellegi potest, debet
    • there is nothing strange in that: neque id mirum est or videri debet
  • debeo in Ramminger, Johann (accessed 16 July 2016) Neulateinische Wortliste: Ein Wörterbuch des Lateinischen von Petrarca bis 1700‎[2], pre-publication website, 2005-2016
